answer.body:
It is the average gross monthly income of all family members in the household over the past 12 months divided by number of family members in the household. Income includes basic income, overtime pay, allowances, cash awards, commissions and bonuses (variables & 13-month, etc.).


Please click here for more information on Means-Testing.

questionListItems.title: Are there any brochures on the different schemes under AIC?

answer.body: Please click here to explore the various brochures on the different schemes under AIC.

topics.title: General information on Agency for Integrated Care

questionListItems.title: What service does Centre-based Respite Care provide (CBRC)?

answer.body:
Centre-based Respite Care services include:-


  • Ensure loved one takes his/her medication, where required

  • Exercise and social activities

  • Help with Activities of Daily Living such as eating, going to the toilet, and moving around

  • Meals

Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: How can I apply for Centre-based Respite Care (CBRC)?

answer.body:
There are two ways to apply for Centre-based Respite Care services:-


1. Apply through a social worker or case manager


If you have a social worker or case manager, you may apply for the service through them. You can also enquire about subsidies with them.


2. Apply directly to a participating day care centre


You can approach your preferred Day Care centre directly. Kindly speak with the centre regarding the services, availability, charges and subsidies.


Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: Is Home Caregiving Grant Scheme (HCG) means tested?

answer.body:
Yes. This grant is means-tested.

The care recipient and his/her household has per capita household monthly income of $2,800 or less, OR belong to a household with no income and living in a residence with Annual Value of less than $13,000.


Please click here for more information about Home Caregiving Grant.

questionListItems.title: If senior is in a nursing home, can I still apply for Home Caregiving Grant Scheme (HCG)?

answer.body:
The new Home Caregiving Grant is intended to support lower- to middle-income households to care for their disabled loved ones in the community, to support ageing in place and delay institutionalisation.

Seniors, who are being taken care of in Nursing Homes will thus, not be eligible for this grant. Nonetheless, they may be eligible for means-tested Government subsidies for their nursing home fees and will not be eligible for this Home Caregiving Grant.


Please click here for more information about Home Caregiving Grant.

The Silver Support Scheme provides additional support for elderly Singaporeans who had low incomes through life and who now have little or no family support. There is no need to apply for Silver Support.


You may call the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board at 1800 227 1188 or click here for more information on the scheme.

questionListItems.title: How can I find out more about nursing homes?

answer.body:
To apply for subsidised nursing home placement, the care recipient must meet all the following criteria:

  • Have physical or mental disabilities because of medical conditions like stroke, dementia and other chronic illnesses.

  • Semi-mobile, wheelchair or bed-bound and need daily nursing care and help in daily living activities such as toileting, walking, etc.

  • Tried all possible care arrangements such as hiring a domestic helper, day care, home care, etc.

  • Not able to be cared for at home by other family members or community providers.

  • Pass the means-test for long-term care subsidies.


Please click here for more information on Nursing Homes.

questionListItems.title: What is the Silver Support Scheme?

answer.body:
The Silver Support Scheme provides additional support for elderly Singaporeans who had low incomes through life and who now have little or no family support. There is no need to apply for Silver Support.


Please click here or call 1800 227 1188 for more information on the Silver Support Scheme.

questionListItems.title: How to re-do Means-Testing if there is a change in the household composition?

answer.body:
If there is a change in the household composition, you will need to resubmit a new Means-Test application.


For details of the means-test assessment, please refer to the Household Means-Test Declaration Form.

questionListItems.title: I am born in 1980 or later and have pre-existing severe disabilities. Will I need to pay premiums for CareShield Life? Why?

answer.body:
All Singaporean Citizens and Permanent Residents born in 1980 or later, including those with pre-existing disabilities in these cohorts, will be able to enjoy protection under CareShield Life, regardless of your ability to pay premiums.

As part of collective responsibility, those with pre-existing disabilities should contribute one premium payment to join the scheme. The payment amount is less than the first monthly CareShield Life payout you will receive. Upon joining the scheme, you will continue to receive monthly payouts for as long as you remain severely disabled.

The Government will provide means-tested premium subsidies, and Additional Premium Support to help those who are still unable to afford premiums even after subsidies. Claims will be paid out as long as insureds meet the claims criteria.

questionListItems.title: I am born in 1979 or earlier. Will I be able to join or upgrade to CareShield Life? What processes do I need to undergo to join CareShield Life?

answer.body:
You can join CareShield Life if you are not severely disabled (i.e. unable to perform 3 or more ADLs) when the scheme commences for those born in 1979 or earlier from end-2021 onwards. Details of the application process will be provided at a later date. Some applicants may need to undergo a disability assessment. Applicants will be informed if they need a disability assessment.

To make joining CareShield Life more convenient, Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents born in 1970 to 1979 will be auto-enrolled in CareShield Life from end-2021, if they are insured under the ElderShield 400 scheme and are not severely disabled at the point of auto-enrolment. They can opt out of CareShield Life by 31 Dec 2023 if they do not wish to join the scheme.

questionListItems.title: I am unable to pay the premiums for the upcoming CareShield Life renewal. Can I seek help from AIC?

answer.body:
Additional Premium Support is designed to help Singapore Citizens or Permanent residents who are needy, unable to afford their CareShield Life premiums even after premium subsidies and have limited family support. If you are eligible, the Government will send you an application inviting you to apply for Additional Premium Support.

For more information on CareShield Life premiums, please visit careshieldlife.gov.sg. For more information on Additional Premium Support, please visit medishieldlife.sg/faqs/aps or call the Healthcare Hotline at 1800-222-3399 for assistance.

questionListItems.title: Should I upgrade to/join CareShield Life? What should I base my decision on?

answer.body:
The Government encourages Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents born in 1979 or earlier, and not severely disabled, to consider joining CareShield Life to ensure they have basic protection for long-term care.

To ensure that CareShield Life premiums are affordable, the Government will provide several premium support measures for those born in 1979 or earlier, when the scheme is made available to them in end-2021:

Means-tested premium subsidies of up to 30% of CareShield Life premiums, to help lower- to middle-income households.

Participation incentives* of up to $2,500 for Singapore Citizens born in 1979 or earlier, if they join within the first two years the scheme is available to them for sign-ups from end-2021.

Additional participation incentives* of $1,500 for Merdeka and Pioneer Generation citizens within the first two years the scheme is available to them for sign-ups from end-2021.

Additional Premium Support for Singapore Citizens who are unable to pay their CareShield Life premiums even after premium subsidies, so that no one will lose coverage under CareShield Life due to an inability to pay premiums.

*Participation incentives will be used to offset the annual premiums payable, to be spread over 10 years of premium payment.

You may wish to refer to the CareShield Life premium calculator at careshieldlife.gov.sg/premium-calculator for information on estimated premiums and premium support. You may also wish to discuss with your financial advisor on your healthcare and financial planning.

[Note: The CareShield Life premium calculator is not available for those born in 1980 or later.]

questionListItems.title: What is the payout amount for CareShield Life? Is it for life?

answer.body:
A successful CareShield Life claimant can receive payouts for the entire duration of severe disability (i.e. for as long as he/she remains severely disabled) and continues to be insured under CareShield Life. This is meant to provide better protection against the uncertainty of long-term care costs.

The potential payout starts at $600 per month in 2020, which increases annually until age 67 or when a successful claim is made, whichever is earlier.

For example, if a 30-year-old individual joined CareShield Life in 2020, is severely disabled and makes a claim in 2020, he/she can potentially receive $600 per month, for the entire duration of severe disability. However, if a 30-year-old individual joined CareShield Life in 2020, and becomes severely disabled at age 67 or later, he/she can potentially receive $1,200 per month upon making a successful claim, for the entire duration of severe disability.

subtopics.title: How to be a Silver Generation Ambassador (SGA)?
